page.title: 09Farming
page.content: Most Consett farms, situated in the Derwnt Valley, are{cattle and sheep farms. Few dairy herds exist as European surpluses required milk to be cut, so cattle are raised for beef. Grass is sown for stock feeding. Rough land is grazed. In some fields, grass is grown six weeks, cut, "wilted" and compressed in black plastic bags. This silage is stored for winter use as "sweet fodder". Artificial and natural fertilizers are spread to encourage a second crop of grass for hay. The hay is machine cut, turned, baled and stored for winter feed. Few 'green' crops are sown although one or two fields of potatoes have been planted.Occasional patches of yellow rape can be seen, grown for it's seed which produces oil.
